001package org.consensusj.jsonrpc;
002
003import java.io.IOException;
004import java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture;
005import java.util.concurrent.Executor;
006import java.util.function.Supplier;
007
008/**
009 * Helper methods for creating asynchronous calls using {@link CompletableFuture}. Since the
010 * synchronous methods in {@link AbstractRpcClient} throw checked exceptions this interface
011 * provides wrapper support to make it easier to convert them to async calls.
012 */
013public interface AsyncSupport {
014    /**
015     * Supply async for a ThrowingSupplier by catching exceptions and completing exceptionally.
016     *
017     * @param throwingSupplier Supplier of T that can throw an {@code IOException}
018     * @param <T> return type
019     * @return A completable future, returning T
020     */
021    default <T> CompletableFuture<T> supplyAsync(ThrowingSupplier<T> throwingSupplier) {
022        return supplyAsync(throwingSupplier, getDefaultAsyncExecutor());
023    }
024
025    /**
026     * Supply async for a ThrowingSupplier by catching exceptions and completing exceptionally.
027     *
028     * @param throwingSupplier Supplier of T that can throw an {@code IOException}
029     * @param executor Executor to run the Supplier
030     * @param <T> return type
031     * @return A completable future, returning T
032     */
033    default <T> CompletableFuture<T> supplyAsync(ThrowingSupplier<T> throwingSupplier, Executor executor) {
034        return AsyncSupport.supplyCatchingAsync(throwingSupplier, executor);
035    }
036
037    /**
038     * Return the default executor for supplying asynchronicity.
039     *
040     * @return An executor.
041     */
042    default Executor getDefaultAsyncExecutor() {
043        return (Runnable r) -> new Thread(r).start();
044    }
045
046    private static <T> CompletableFuture<T> supplyCatchingAsync(ThrowingSupplier<T> throwingSupplier, Executor executor) {
047        CompletableFuture<T> future = new CompletableFuture<>();
048        executor.execute(() -> {
049            try {
050                T result = throwingSupplier.getThrows();
051                future.complete(result);
052            } catch (IOException e) {
053                future.completeExceptionally(e);
054            }
055        });
056        return future;
057    }
058
059    /**
060     * Subinterface of {@link Supplier} for Lambdas which throw {@link IOException}.
061     * Can be used for two purposes:
062     * <ol>
063     *     <li>To cast a lambda that throws an {@code IOException} to a {@link Supplier} while
064     *      automatically wrapping any exception thrown by the lambda with {@link RuntimeException}.</li>
065     *     <li>As a {@code FunctionalInterface} where a lambda that throws exceptions is
066     *      expected or allowed.</li>
067     * </ol>
068     * This is intended to be used to wrap JSON-RPC I/O methods of {@link JsonRpcClient} that throw {@link IOException} and
069     * subclasses such as {@link JsonRpcException}, so we have narrowed the allowed exceptions in {@link #getThrows()} to
070     * {@link IOException}.
071     *
072     * @param <T>
073     */
074    @FunctionalInterface
075    interface ThrowingSupplier<T> extends Supplier<T> {
076
077        /**
078         * Gets a result wrapping checked Exceptions with {@link RuntimeException}
079         * @return a result
080         */
081        @Override
082        default T get() {
083            try {
084                return getThrows();
085            } catch (final Exception e) {
086                throw new RuntimeException(e);
087            }
088        }
089
090        /**
091         * Gets a result.
092         *
093         * @return a result
094         * @throws IOException A (checked) exception
095         */
096        T getThrows() throws IOException;
097    }
098}
